headline: CNN 10
subHeadline: Controversial Plan To Release Treated Wastewater from The Fukushima Nuclear Disaster Into The Pacific Ocean; Feeding the Astronauts During Long Duration Missions; Dog Ate Groom`s Passport Days Before Couple`s Wedding in Italy. Aired 4-4:10a ET

utterances.speaker: COREN
utterances.sentences: The International Atomic Energy Agency backs Japan`s plan to slowly feed the water into the sea, but not all the dangerous elements can beremoved. A level of the hydrogen isotope called radioactive tritium will remain in the water. Japan and the IAEA says it`s safe in small amounts.

utterances.speaker: RAFAEL GROSSI, INTERNATIONAL ATOMIC ENERGY AGENCY
utterances.sentences: Tritium is present there in a very, very low concentration. And it will be diluted even further to apoint that it will be negligible.

utterances.speaker: COREN
utterances.sentences: The concentration of tritium released is set to come under the World Health Organization`s regulatory limit, but such assurances have not beenenough to assuage the fears of many in Japan and around the region. UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE (through translator): I don`t believe it at all. It`s very dangerous. It contains very radioactive substances. It would become a serious problem once it`s released into the ocean. We won`t be able to eat fish anymore.

utterances.speaker: COREN
utterances.sentences: Protests have been a constant since Japan announced its plan to release the water two years ago. Many worry about the potential forbioaccumulation of dangerous elements in the ecosystem. While neighboring countries like China have accused Japan of treating the ocean as a dumping ground. But the disaster of 2011 left Japan with few options.

utterances.speaker: GROSSI
utterances.sentences: This would not happen in a normal operation of a nuclear reactor. Here you had all this accumulation and then you had to deal with it. Youhad to take a decision.

utterances.speaker: COREN
utterances.sentences: Many difficult decisions will need to be made at Fukushima in the coming decades. Part of the reason to release the stored water is to freeup space to safely decommission the plant. The legacy of the Fukushima Nuclear Disaster will be a lasting one. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Ten second trivia.With current technology, how long would it take for humans to make a roundtrip to Mars? Six months, one year, two to three years, at least 15 years? According to NASA, a crude mission to Mars and back would take two to three years. If you are going to be floating in space for two to three years, what one food would you want to eat? Have you ever heard of the deep space food challenge? It`s an international competition put on by NASA and the Canadian Space Agency to find ways to create healthy tasty foods for astronauts on long missions, like roundtrip to Mars. CNN Space and Science Writer Ashley Strickland takes us to a culinary lab in San Francisco for more. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) PHNAM BAGLEY, CO-FOUNDER & CREATIVE DIRECTOR, NONFICTION DESIGN: So, one thing to know about food in space is like your taste buds are not functioning. The same way as they are when you`re on the surface. The food that we give astronauts is actually quite pungent --

utterances.speaker: ASHLEY STRICKLAND, CNN SPACE AND SCIENCE WRITER
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: -- for them to even feel anything.

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: Yeah. So --

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: Good strong flavors, right?

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: It`s not going to be subtle.STRICKLAND (voice-over): Keeping astronauts healthy on long missions in space presents many challenges and food is a big one. Phnam Bagley is the Co-Founder of Nonfiction, a design firm that is one of several finalists in a NASA and Canadian Space Agency Competition called the Deep Space Food Challenge.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: So going to Mars, and you take two and a half, three years roundtrip, and astronauts can only eat so many freeze-dried, rehydratedfood before they go crazy.

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: So what are some of these greens that we`re seeing here?

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes. So this is an aeroponic garden, so you can see some baby bok choy, you can see some like butter greens.STRICKLAND (voice-over): Nonfiction calls this a Culinary Lab. It`s a working mockup of a modular unit that can fit into a spacecraft. It grows food has a coffee maker and can even grill meat.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: As we all know open fires are frowned upon in space.

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: Right, yeah.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: So, let`s avoid that, right?

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: So what we decide to do is to use basically microwave to heat up the meat and then to essentially draw the grill pattern on the proteinusing laser. There we go.

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: So this little real mark on top, kind of like depending on how wet the -- the top surface was. But makes this piece of chicken look a lot moreappetizing, right? Space barbecue.

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: Space barbecue.(Voice-over): This part of the culinary lab is what Nonfiction calls munch, it`s a bioreactor that grows algae that can be harvested and eaten by the astronauts.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: So what we do is that we extract these little discs of microalgae, and then eventually we get a lot of it.

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: And then this smells terrible and it doesn`t taste great, but it`s very nutritious. So what we do is that to hide the flavor, we actually mixit with a lot of different types of ingredients here. You are in a Silicon bag and then you mix it up.

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: And then it ends up as balls like this. And you can keep these for, you know, two or three days, and they`ll still taste pretty fresh.

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: I feel like I`m going to have a special meal. I`m excited.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: There you go. Astronaut food. It`s the future.

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: Here`s the space food.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: Still better, right?

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: It tastes really good. You got the peanut butter.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: And oats. It`s really nice texture.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: That`s delicious.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: Great.

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: I could absolutely -- I could eat this all the time.

utterances.speaker: BAGLEY
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.

utterances.speaker: STRICKLAND
utterances.sentences: That`s really good.(Voice-over): It`s not just that Intrepid space fearing humans need food to stay alive. The preparation taste and appearance of food can have real psychological benefits for astronauts. (END VIDEOTAPE)
